div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English daily Newspaper, established 1880.
Price One Plastre Tariff.
WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 4. 1905.
AFTER PORT ARTHUR.

The fall of Port Arthur has necessarily brought up the question of mediation or in- ervention, and a telegram from London this morning states that various inspired sug- estions in the direction of peace are emanating from Washington, representing Mr. Roosevelt as anxious to mediate but unable to move until approached by both the belligerents. Nothing whatever confirmatory has been receiv ed, and the peaee rumors are not credited. The scepticism prevailing in London is doubt- less well founded for we are still unable to believe that peace is near at hand. The fall of

Port Arthur does not necessarily imply that the Japanese will triumph in the war, for the capitulation of the Gibraltar of the Far East is probably only the end of the first act, and not by any means the drop scene, of the great drama. We believe that Ruarsa will fight to the bitter end, subject always to the condition that there is no general internal revolt. Such an occurrence is possible if the peasantry have ceased to fear a beaten Government, or are convinced that the war will drain them of too much of their strength, and if the soldiery are unwilling to put insurrection down ; but it seems to us most improbable. Very few Rus- sians realise what the loss of sea-power means, and fewer still are fully convinced that it has been lost. There has been no invasion, no cap- ture of any ancient Russian city, nothing to enable an unusually ignorant population to see the war. They feel the draft made on them by the summons to the Reserves, and they are disturbed by rumours that Holy Russia is not crushing her enemies with her usual com- pleteness ; but there has been no disaster sufficiently visible to destroy the mingled fear and reepect felt for the authority of the Tsar, or to induce the people to run the terrible risks involved in any insurrection not supported by the soldiery. So long as there is obedience the governing group in St. Petersburg can go on with the war if it will; and its material resources, except at sea, are not yet worn out, or even seriously affected. Even if the Russians have lost in the campaign two hundred thousand men through the hardships of transport, the out- bursts of sickness, and the deaths in actual fighting, these losses will soon be replaced by the conscription, more especially as most of the dead belonged to the Asiatic side of the vast Empire. The losses of officers, which have been frightful, are being made up. Better artillery, better powder, better muni- tions altogether, are all procurable for money; and the idea that the wealth of Russia has been-exhausted in less than a year of war is positively inept. The Treasury must provide for the interest on the Debt, and for all that is purchased abroad; but it has reserves of gold to meet those necessities, and everything procur- able at home can be paid for in paper, to be redeemed on the conclusion of the war. There are plenty of resources for a secoond campaign, and the great Russians are, as we believe, determined to fight one. They have at least three sets of motives, any one of which would induce them to adopt that course. They are as proud of Russia as we are of Great Britain, and would feel ultimate defeat by an Asiatic Power as an inexpiable shame. They are firmly convinced that their defeat has been due to unpreparedness, mismanagement, and corruption, and believe that with a few months for reorganisation they can collect a mighty army, resume the offensive, and in the next campaign drive the Japanese into the sea. And the governing classes feel, rather than see, that a shameful peace, especially if it included an indemnity, would be fatal to the autocracy; that is, would, in their judgment, be the precursor of anarchy, and probably of dismemberment.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR’S FALL
CAPITULATION CONDITIONS
RUSSIAN WRECKAGE.
NEWS NOT KNOWN IN RUSSIA.
div.p: Port Arthur, January 3.
The capitulation of the town was signed at 9.45 yesterday evening.
(Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, January 3.
The fall of Port Arthur is unknown to the general public. It has hitherto only been known to the official world, and to certain restricted private circles.
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 3.
In the conditions of the capitulation of Port Arthur, it is stipulated that the officers of the garrison will return to Russia on parole and the men will be sent to Japan as prisoners.
(Havas.)
Tokio, January 3.
The Russian officers will be permitted to return to Russia on parole. They will retain their swords. The Japanese occupied a number of forts to-day.

The Japanese are very annoyed at the destruction of the ships arid the despatching of destroyers after the oiler to surrender. The newspapers, in consequence of such action, demand that the garrison shall receive severe treatment. It appears, however, that the destruction, etc., occurred after a Council of War had decided upon surrender but consider- ably before the Commissioners met.
(Reuter.)
Chi-Fu, January 3.
Three torpedo-launches have arrived from Port Arthur. There are now 7 Japanese destroyers in the harbour.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, January 3.
Apparently all the Russian destroyers reach- ed Chi-Fu and Tsingtan safely. The Russians destroyed all the men-of-war, and wrecked the remaining forts, together with everything valuable.
(Reuter.)

div.head: EUROPEAN PRESS OPINION
div.p: London, January 3.

All the comments of Europe and America agree that the fall of Port Arthur will conclude a military drama without parallel in history, on account of the valour and achievements of the victors, and the heroism and devotion of the vanquished. It is thought that the war will continue unabated.
The Standard states that the end has been worthy of that marvelous conflict between men who were equally matched as regards an inexhaustible resource of unflinching courage and un ailing endurance.
The Morning Post says that the capture of the fortress is one of the finest feat of arms on record.
The Daily Telegraph states that the attack, demanding appalling sacrifices, has crowned the victors with glory.
(Reuter.)

div.head: BALTIC FLEET.
MEETING OF TI1E SQUADRONS.
div.p: Passandava Bay, January 3.
Admiral Foelkersahm’s squadron is anchored here.
Admiral Rodjtstvensky’s squadron is now at Autongil. Both squadrons are provisioning at Nossi Be, Mojanga, and Tamatave.
It is believed their rendezvous will be Diego Suarez.
(Reuter.)
Tananarive, January 3.
Admiral Foelkersahm’s squadron has anchor- ed in Passandava Bay.
(Havas.)

div.head: PEACE RUMOURS.
div.p: London, January 3.

Various inspired suggestions in the direction of peace are emanating from Washington, re- presenting Mr. Roosevelt as anxious to mediate but unable to move until approached by both the belligerents. Nothing whatever con- firmatory has been received here, and the peace rumours are not Credited.
(Reuter.)

div.head: A MUNIFICENT GIFT.
div.p: London, January 3.
Lord Mount Stephen has given £200,000 to the King’s Hospital Fund.
(Reuter.)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
HELOUAN SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: We are requested to state that Prince Mohamed Aly was present at the Helouan Sporting Club’s meeting and acted as judge. His Highness spared no paint to make the meeting a success. Prince Abbas Pasha Halim was also present.
In the Sahara Stakes the order was: Bibieo 1st, Sattam 2nd, and Aeolus 3rd, while in the Desert Handicap Mizzaud was 1st and Royalist last.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Cairo Water Company.—Sir Elwin Palmer has been appointed member of the board of the Cairo Water Company, in succession to the late Tigrane Pasha.
The French Gunboat “Raoce” arrived at Port Said from Algiers on Monday after- noon, and leaves for Djibouti on the 6th inst. She is commanded by Capt L Blanc.
Judge Assessors. — The election of judge assessors for the Alexandria Mixed Courts will take place in the hall of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunal on Monday next at 3.30 p.m.
Accession Day. — On the accession day of H.H. the Khedive, a fete will be held in the Ghezireh Gardens and a special performance will be given at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo.
Cairo Dogs.—Large numbers of dogs are being poisoned and shot by the Cairo police in the city, but as fast as they disappear others come from Ghizeh and Galioubieb, so that little effect is noticed.

Another Record Cargo of live stock ar- rived here yesterday from Alexandretta by the Bell’s Asia Minor SS. “Bravo” (Capt J. M. Laron), viz, 3,177 sheep and 87 bullocks, besides about 450 packages of merchandise.

Zizinia Theatre.—The performance of Tris tano e Isotta yesterday evening, though well given, received rather a cold reception at the hands of a fairly large audience. Adrienne Le- couereur to-night should draw a crowded house.

Fire at Alexandria.— A fire broke out early this morning in a grocery and spirit shop in Sharia el-Warsha. The fire originated among a quantity of packets of matches, which ignited some mastic and paper. The damage is esti- mated at about L.E. 10.

Shepheard’s.—The grand ootillon ball to be given to-night at Shepheard’s promises to be an enormous success, as over 800 persons are expected to be present, including many of the leading members of Cairo society. Persons who have not received invitations will not be admitted.
Church Services.—On Friday next, the festival of the Epiphany, the services at St. Mark’s, Alexandria, and All Saints,’ Ramleh, will be as follows:
St. Mark's.—8 am. Holy Communion. 11 am. Morning Prayer. 6.15 p.m. Evening Prayer. All Saints'.—8 a.m. Holy Communion. 4.80 p.m. Evening Prayer.

Double Murder for- P.T. 50.—The Keneh Native Court has passed sentence of death on one Hussein Darwish, of the village of Barak- ma, Keneh Markaz, who was found guilty of the murder of both his uncle and aunt. Some time ago he deposited with his victims the sum of P.T.50,for the return of which he had applied on more than one occasion. His uncle, being in poor circumstances, was unable to pay the money and always postponed the time for doing so. At last, when the man’s patience was ex- hausted, he took a knife, went to his uncle’s house, and murdered both him and his wife, afterwards confessing his guilt to the Parquet.

St. Joseph’s Home, in the Moharrem Bey quarter of Alexandria, gave a delightful Christ- mas Tree fete yesterday. A large number of ladies were present including Mme. Girard, Mrs. Chataway, Countess de Zogheb, etc. The fine Christmas Tree was given by Mr. von Pitner. It was bedecked with innumerable toys and beautifully illuminated. The tree had been decorated by the ladies who organis- ed the fete. The delight of the children who are so well looked after at this excellent insti- tution was a treat to behold, and gave a well deserved pleasure to the lady patronesses, who had been at great pains to organise the fete for the children. The fete was in the first place due to the initiative of Mrs. G. Debbane, who was kindly assisted by the “Dames de l'Ouvroir des Mires Chretiennes” and by many young ladies of Alexandria.

The Egyptian Slave Trade. — An Anglo- Egyptian abolitionist has passed away by the death in London a few days ago of Mr. Charles H. Allen, F.R.G.S., who was for 19 years secre- tary of the British and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society, in his 81st year. Mr. Allen came of a Quaker stock. Throughout his life he showed special interest in the development of Africa. At first his attention was largely concentrated on Egypt, where the British Government had, recently undertaken great responsibilities. He received invaluable assistance from General Gordon in pressing for the abolition of slavery and the slave-trade throughout the Egyptian dominions; and seldom did General Gordon come to London without visiting Mr. Allen to discuss some plan for the liberation of the mil lions in the Dark Continent. A warm coadjutor was found from the first in Lord Cromer, who rendered splendid help, both by his general policy and also by promoting individual schemes such as the Home for Freed Woman Slaves in Cairo.
GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITORS.
DUKE OF'CONNAUGHT’S ARRIVAL
div.p: It is now expected that H.M.S “Essex,” conveying T.R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught to Egypt, will come to Alexandria, and not Port Said, as was originally reported.
The Royal visitors will be met on their arri- val here by H.H. the Khedive, who will after- wards accompany them to Cairo.
H.I.H. the Archduke Otto of Austria has left Cairo for a caravan trip in the Sinai peninsula, which will last for about three weeks.
H.R.H. the Crown Prince of Norway and Sweden is expected at Shepheard's Hotel on the 10th inst

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has been paying a visit to his estates at Mariout.
The State ball at Abdeen Palace will take place on or about the 20th inst.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL HOUSEHOLD.
div.p: The Khedivial Household has been reor ganised at follows : Ahmed Bey Chefik has been appointed director of the Arabic and European bureaux and Mohamed Bey Izzet is to be head of the Turkish section. The post of secretary-general is suppressed and replaced by that of first clerk to the Khedivial secretarist to be filled by Chawki Bey. Ravon Bey is to be chief of the archives department. Harris Bey Fahmy and M. Oudin Bey remain chief of the Arabic and European bureaux respec tively.

div.head: ACCESSION HONORS.
div.p: The list of Accession Honors will be pu- blished in the next numbers of the Journal Official.

div.head: HONOR FOR BREWSTER BEY.
div.p: The announcement that the Khedive has bestowed the grade of Grand Officer (2nd class)of the Order of the Medjidieh on his English private secretary will be received with great pleasure by the members of the British colony, among whom Brewster Bey counts many friends. The Bey has been 35 years in the service of the Egyptian Government, having entered the Customs Administration and Coastguard Service in 1870. In 1879 he was appointed Director of Customs at Suakin by the late General Gordon. This post he held till 1882, when he served in the Egyptian campaign on the Commissarist stall (medal and bronze star). He returned to Suakin in 1883, and served under Baker Pasha in the Intelligence and Commissarist Department and was subsequently appointed by the late Admiral Sir W.. Hewitt as Sub Governor, in addition to his duties at the Customs. In 1884 he was appointed Commander of the Imperial Order of the Medjidieh, and in the following year he was lent to the Intelligence Depart- ment by the Egyptian Government, and was attached to General Graham’s force. He was present at several actions and at the taking of Tamai, being mentioned in despatches. He remained in Suakin as Director of Customs until 1890, when he was transferred to the Coastguard Service at Alexandria as Secretary and Controller. In 1891 he was selected by the Khedive Mohamed Tewtik as his Private Secretary, and acts now in the same capacity to the present Khedive, his son. He already holds the rank of Bey of the first class, and is Commander of the Imperial Ottoman Orders of Osmanieh and Medjidieh, and Chevalier of the Francois Joseph Order.

div.head: MOTORS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The motor car is becoming, more and more one of the regular features of the traffic of the Capital, and it is satisfactory to note that the drivers are showing a reasonable regard for the convenience and safety of the public. There is one point, however, as to which it seems desirable to draw their attention. This is that the mere fact of their having a good clear stretch of road before them does not justify their driving at high speeds in narrow streets or near footpaths occupied by pedestrians. At any moment a tyre may burst, with the im- mediate consequence of whirling the car sud- denly round to the right or left, and plunging it into the midst of a crowd of passers-by with- out leaving these a chance of escape. Several fatal accidents have already occurred in Europe in this way.

div.head: SHOUBRA BRIDGE SUBWAY.
div.p: The new subway under the railway, that was to have been opened for public use during last month, is still far from complete, and we shall in all probability be well on into the new year before it will, or indeed can, be opened, The roadway has been pierced and the side walls built, but the iron roofing has yet to be fixed and the approaches constructed, and this means no small amount of labor. That, when completed, it will prove a great relief to the foot traffic over the Shoubra Bridge there can be no doubt, but, if it is to be rendered really effective, it will have to be placed under constant supervision, both with regard to the uses it may be put to and for the prevention of obstructions and blocking. Very much of its utility will depend upon the approaches, as if these are not convoniently placed and arranged they will very largely discount the value of the accommodation the tunnel will afford.

div.head: PILGRIMAGE REGULATIONS.
NOTE BY THIS GOVERNMENT.
div.p: A Note has been issued by the Government of explaining its intentions in imposing the regulations of this year upon the pilgrimage. The Note points out that, so far from in any way exploiting the pilgrims for its own profit, it has to pay a considerable charge to the Khedivial Steamship Company, being obliged to guarantee a minimum number of pilgrim passengers in return for the reduction of their fare.

The Government points out that the oscort of the Mahmal has been increased to 400 men, causing an additional expense of L.E. 5,000. The pilgrims, of whom 1,614 have expressed their desire to accompany tho Mahmal, will thus benefit by obtaining greater security and the best medical care that can be provided.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Today’s bulletin records a fatal case and two deaths at Suez.

div.head: CASE OF-PLAGUE ON STEAMER.
div.p: The SS “City of Agra,” which arrived at Suez yesterday- from Calcutta, had on board a suspected case of plague. The steamer was disinfected by the quarantine authori ties and the patients were conveyed to Moses Wells for treatment.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN TURKEY.
div.p: Pera, January 3
Vessels from Suez which have left since the 1st inst, with pilgrims or passengers, undergo five days quarantine and disinfection, vessels without passengers or pilgrims 24 hours and disinfection.

div.head: EFFECT OF LONDON FOG.
div.p: Port Said, Tuesday. — The P & O. SS “Mongolia,” which in the ordinary course of her run should have reached Port Said today (Tuesday), is not now expected to arrive until Thursday morning, her starting time having been delayed by the great London fog two days before Christmas.

Tips will not affect the mails for Egypt as I the “Osiris" is due to arrive at the usual time to-morrow. Fortunately the speed capabilities of the "Mongolia" will enable her to make up for the delay before reaching Sydney.

div.head: NATIVE THEATRE AT SUEZ BURNT.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday.—A few days ago, a native theatrical company came to Suez and erected in the centre of the town a wooden theatre covered with awnings. Last evening, at 7.30 on the occasion of the first performance, a crowd of natives assembled at the theatre, but did not enjoy the play for very long, as a lamp set fire to the canvas and the whole place was in a very short time burnt to the ground.' A panic ensued amongst the spectators, but they all managed to escape uninjured. The Fire Brigade arrived on the scene promptly and rendered every assistance, but the engine could not be made use or as the firemen were unable to get up steam.

div.head: PORT-SAID CATHOLIC SEAMEN’S CLUB.
div.p: On Thursday, 29th ult, a sumptuous tea and impromptu concert was given at the above club to the seamen in port. The rooms had been tastefully decorated for the occasion, and the tables were beautifully laid with large supplies of cake, sandwiches, and fruit. About 40 seamen sat down to partake of the treat offered them. After the tea, which was served by lady, visitors, a concert followed, and the men cheerfully came forward to sing songs. During the concert cigars, cigarettes, sand- wiches, and refreshments were served, and the greatest cordiality and good feeling prevailed throughout, though the men were of divers nationalities, creeds, and color. The meeting broke up at 10p.m., all those present standing up to sing “God save the King.”
The committee are deeply grateful to the ladies who so kindly volunteered their services, and also to several friends who contributed in other ways to the success of the evening.

div.head: A NEW SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: The Pall Mall Gazette makes the following remarks on the interview which we reproduced from the Standard on Monday last:- If any- thing were needed to confirm the rumours , afloat regarding the construction of an altern- , ative canal between the Mediterranean and Red Sea, we should imagine the interview with M. Bonnet, the secretary of the Suez Canal Company, published in the Standard, would, sufficient. This gentleman denies nothing, but in the course of a columm of commonplace remarks he asserts that his company has a monopoly for seventy years to come. Such a statement will cause not a little surprise in London, and, we should imagine, to the shade Mr. Gladstone. To those behind the scenes Mn Bonnet’s ingenuousness is quite refreshing, for the leaders of the agitation for a new 1anal are hard at work upon their scheme. How long will it be before Prince d’Arenberg follows the example of the late M. de Lesseps, who, after protesting that he would concede nothing, came to London to find out on what terms shipowners would oonsont to make peace.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner “Tabor" arrived here this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Malta and Tripoli, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: TRAGEDY AT ALEXANDRIA
TWO MEN KILLED
div.p: A fatal quarrel took place yesterday after- noon between three Greeks in a bar behind the Attarin Bazaar. The parties all hail from Smyrna, and tt appeara that the mur- derer loved a sister of his two victims, one of whom was a suitor for his own sister's hand. A discussion arose between the men and the murderer drew his knife and despatch- ed one at the brothers with a single stab. The other brother came to the rescue but received two stabs, to which he succumbed in the Greek Hospital at midnight.

The murderer is a young man, about 20 years of age, and is extraordinarily muscular. His name is Yanni Antonio Stigrigo, and he was arrested by tho polioe in front of Cairo Railway Station. He made no resistance to the police and allowed himself to be handcuffed quitely.
He is a native subject and was taken before the Native Parquet at midday today.

div.head: IMPORTANT DISCOVERY.
div.p: The Service of Antiquities has recently undertaken excavations at the low stone pyramid of Zawyet el Arayan, which lies on the desert plateau between Ghizieh and Sak- karah. The site dates from the Ancient Empire and news has just been received of the discovery of a large granite mastaba or tomb. Strong hopes are entertained that a find of considerable magnitude is about to be un- covered. Extensive subterranean galleries were excavated some years ago, but, owing to the difficult descent at the entrance shaft, visitors rarely go down to these long passages under the desert.

div.head: PROF. MASPERO'S NEW TRANSLATION.
div.p: M. Maspero has published a new translation of the stele of Userkaf (the Usercheres of Manetho) of the fifth dynasty, found by Prof. Petrie at Abydos. He thinks that if Prof. Petrie's copyist had been, as he says, “a professional Egyptologist," he (or she) might have been ablo to make a guess at many of the mutilated signs, and thus have oonsidorahly reduced the lacuna in the copy from which we now have to work. He does not agree with Mr. Griffith in the view that the inscription was originally written on papyrus, and afterwards transferred to stone, and he corrects the translation published by the last-named in 'Abydos IL' in several particulars. M. Maspero has also given a criticism of Dr. Erman’s recent ’Aegyptisches Glosaar,' in which he laments that Dr. Erman refers his readers in certain cases to his grammar only, and not to the texts on which it is supposed to be founded. As M Maspero says, it is necessary for beginners even more than for more advanced scholars that they should have an opportunity of check- ing for themselves the theories of the Berlin school, without being forced jurare in verbum magistri. Perhaps the sting of his criticism ies in the concluding words that the 'Gloasar' should prove useful to students at German universities and beginners in other countries.

div.head: VERDI THEATRE DEBACLE.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes:—

I see that the Verdi Theatre performances are few and far between at present, that ap- patently the company are losing over the ven- ture, in short, that they are likely enough to give it all up. It is the greatest possible pity. Here we have good, an excellent opera com- pany giving us just the repertoire which should appeal to us. The weary resident and the gay visitor do not usually want overmuch Wagner or the like ; they prefer these lighter operas, and yet no one seems to go. I admit that the Verdi Theatre has had one or two off-nights, viz, and to wit, Gioconda for one; but Mignon, Aida, Carmen, Otello, all were excellent. They have a surprisingly good orchestra. They have five or six leading players who are good enough for anything—Signora Monti-Baldini, Signor Tomisani, Signora Popovici—and I was told that Signora Svicher was very good. I have not been, I admit, to all the performances—by no means—but I have heard about those I did not see.

I will say at once that the raison d'etre of this article is not personal in any sense; it is more an expression of my wish to tell Cairo people in general (so far as they take any notice of my valued criticism) that if they wish to see a good light opera oompany, they havo the chance and I wish they would take it. It is pitiful to see the house emptier and emptier, and the performers less and less enthusiastic or inclined to do their best And I should imagine it is certain enough that if this Company gives up this their first attempt we shall get little enough chance of any further repetitions. I admit the locality is annoying, but the swift Cairo cabs make this of little account. Once in a way it may be said by some that they-let us put it so— prefer the environment, internal as well as external, of the Khedivial Opera House, but they can always take a box. And really it was the sight of those many empty boxes which moved me, as could no free seats or first-night suppers or other induce- ments (which same I haven’t had), to cover two sheets of paper — that, and the wish to hear the operas myself, for, O well- beloved visitors and residents, if you don’t en- courage the opera, the opera will vanish, and I shall have to go without! Invade the boxes, then, ye visitors and we, “poor devils on a fixed income," will, lessen our supply of ciga- rettes, and set apart the piastres necessary for our postri numerati, blessing you in that our economy is not unrewarded

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: General von Herwarth is expected at Shep- heard's Hotel shortly
Mr. MaeMillan, the American explorer, will arrive at Khartoum from the South in a few day's time. Mr. Jesseu, who has been staying at Shepheard’s Hotel, will meet him at Khar- toum.
M. Raoul Pugno, the celebrated French pianist is expected to pay a visit to Egypt shortly. He will give a few recitals at Cairo and Alexandira.
The marriage of Mr. Antonio Huri to Mias Natalina Montano will take plaae at St Cathe- rine's Cathedral on Saturday, next.

The following passengers left for the Nile trip by the “Rameses the Great" yesterday; Dr. and Mrs Aufschlager, Dr. and Mrs. Bell Pettigrew, Mr. F. div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondants, but we wish in a spirit of fair play to all to permit-withing certain necessary limits- free discourse.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Sir,-was "Cariene's" object to drive my nails home, or stir up the dry bones in the almost forgotten valley of satire? Preeuming he latter, I pick up a bone here and there and offer you the “bouquet"

Most decidedly,“Cairene,” the “philanthropic (why not philo-progenitive) labors" should have some “forthcoming,” and if the Anglo- American Hospital is to have the honor of presenting our dual community with fifteen new members “at one and the same time" more power to it (the hospital); long may it flourish (the hospital again); also the “fifteen at one and the same time" (A happy new year to them); also the thirty proud responsibilities (A happy new year to them too). But was it not as you infer, a little invidious to call upon the resident civilian community to share the responsibility and add another "embarrassment" fifteen of them to their “present financial" ones

By all means “Cairene," agitate for State- aided lying-in hospitals, and impose penalties on those who do not make use of them, but why a private community, bachelors and bene- dicts alike, should be called upon. to “lay out” to the tune of fifteen ‘lying-in’’ embarrass- ments at a time, and which they had not bar- gained for, is just a little too much.

And why, “Cairene,” do you laud and damn in the same breath the “recent opening of a similar establishment in Cairo,” when the “highest medical authorities have apparently fixed upen Ghezireh as the one and only site for an ideal fresh-air-lying-in-laying-out show. Come, come,—I mean “Go to” (no dash, Mr. Comp, please, I am quoting Shakespeare), Cairene.
I am, etc,
Medico.
Cairo. January 1.

div.head: VANDALISM AT CANOPUS
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir,—Your criticisms on the lack of initiative of the Alexandria Archaeological Society to reference to the state of affairs prevailing on the property of Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun at Aboukir may be absolutely correct, but I should like to point out that the society suffers from a chronic impecuniosity, due to the fact that it is so poorly supported by the public of Alexandria. I use the phrase "chronic im- pecuniosity" in a comparative sense, for if the society's means were greater, it would indulge in far more extensive operations. Considering the grant that the Egyptian Government accords to the Museum Service, it is absurd that the Alexandria Archaeological Society should depend on private contributions.
I am, etc,
Von Clamantis
Alexandria, January 3.

div.head: EGYPT’S TRADE. BRITISH INTERESTS.
div.p: The following article appeared in the latest issue to hand of the London Morning Post-

British trade with Egypt still compares favorably with that between the Khedive's subjects and any other nation. In round figures a third of the total imports are taken from this country, and a part of the remainder from our various colonies and possessions. It would appear, therefore, that there is greater reason to express satisfaction with such results than to utter any words of criticism or warn- ing. Yet a study of the import figures given in the latest issue of the journal of the British Chamber of Commerce in Egypt and of some of the consular remarks which the directors of the publication bare deemed it expedient to quote shows that complaisant satisfaction is not the attitude which it is desirable to com- mend. The reason is that we are not keeping the proportion of trade hitherto enjoyed. Egypt, as we have frequently pointed out, is making great strides forward as a buyer and as a seller. She is most fortunate inn having author- ities who are keenly alive to the development of all those means of transport which act as incentives to commerce. In this journal of the Chamber of Commerce we find a reoord which serves as a pertinent illustration of readiness to meet the views of the trading classes. Some years ago it was urged on these authorities that the Mahmoudieh Canal was not doing the amount or work of which it was capable.^. Abolition of the lock and bridge tolls was advocated with a view to facilitating navigation and increasing trade. In 1900 the tolls were in operation and the total number of boats which passed Atfeh was four thousand five hundred and sixty-four. In 1901 the tolls were abolished and the number passing rose to sixteen thousand seven hundred and twelvo, while last year it was twenty-three thousand and ninety-nine. At Kafr-Dawar lock the total in 1900 was thirteen thousand seven hundred and twenty-four, and last year it was thirty-five thousand seven hundred and thirty-two. These are amazing figures. Strong representations are now being made in favor of improving the facilities tor landing - goods at Cairo, and when this is carried out the water trans- port, especially by means of low-height sailing vessels, will be of far greater use and value. At the same time it should be remembered that Lord Farrer and Mr. Oliver K. H. Bury are engaged in a special inquiry as to the administration ot the State railways of Egypt, and it is expected that they will be able to make suggestions fur improving the efficiency of the public sen ice. Egypt, therefore, presents an attractive field which other nations are' ready to work to the greatest advantage. British trade, while holding a "very com- manding position," has to meet increasingly strong competition in almost all directions. The Earl of Cromer urges on his oouutry- men "greater adaptability to tho "wants of customers” not only in the form of the goods but also in the language and trade terns of circulars and prioe lists. His Lord ship regards the employment of more an 1 better-equipped travelling agents as a matter ot yet greater importance. Kecommeudatioua of the kind are so frequent that they lose some of their force. A glance over detailed figures of import for the first nine months of this year shows bow severe competition is in trades which we have developed to a high degree of efficiency. Of eighty .thousand pounds worth of boots only ten thousand pounds worth oarne from this country. We supply but a tenth of the imported furniture, and about tho same of the glass and china, though in earthen- ware tho percentage is far more in our favor. In brass, copper, and bronze we are masters, and send about two-thirds of the total, while in iron and ironwork our pro- portion is nearly four-fifths, and we send twice as much machinery aa all other countries. But we have but a small share of the ironmongery trade, and we are badly beaten in locomotives and irrigation pumps, though in portable engines it is Great Britain first and this rest practically nowhere. The figures suggest that oertain of our trades have made a great effort to meet Egyptian wants, and hare been successful, while in other direc- tions there has been that absence of adaptabi- lity whereon Lord Cromer comments. We do not draw attention to the state of trade for exclusively commercial reasons. The substan- tial advantage we enjoy ia well worth preserv- ing, and the outlook ia good enough to justify us in regarding Egypt as one of the best of the neutral markets. But there are also political reaaona for desiring to see our trade with the Khedive's possessions pros- pering. Though for the moment the pres- sure of international jealousies is relaxed, and wc may not feel embarrassed by the peculiarly undefined and almost (indefinable nature of' our relations with Egypt, it is im- portant to strengthen all the ties of interest that bind us to that country. Our predominant share of her trade is one of the solid grounds on which our protectorate may be justified, and its existence is an evidence that the relations which have boon established are not even sen- timentally irksome to the people. They will do more business with us if we are equal to the task of meeting every form of rivalry with skill and energy. Egypt noeds our manufactures, and is not likely to be a competitor against them. We, on the other hand, need her pro- duce as raw material for many of our indus- tries, so that there is a natural basis of per- manent exchange, from which the advantages should be mutual.

div.head: NORTH NILE VALLEY, LTD.
div.p: In addressing the shareholders at the annual general meeting of this company, the Chairman said that owing. to delays m obtaining the oomplete accounts from Egypt, it had been found impossible to paci before them the accounts for the year, and it was proposed to have tho utx.unis completed to the end of 1904, and present thorn early in the present year. He was pleased to be able to say that thuir third exp tlition had now been sumo time at the mine, that work was progressing there rapidly and with excellent results, gold was being contin- uously sloped out, and monthly returns were being made, and unless some uuforaaeea diffi- culties arose there was every reason to believe that they would continue. The company was funned to take over an area on the N do Valley Company's concession. That area was held by them under a sub-licence, which expires in March, 1906. The directors have now obtained an extension of their Haimur holding for a further period of two years. They have also obtained mining leases of tho Haimur mines direct from tho Egyptian - Uovenuuout fora period of thirty years, with the right to renew for' a further period of filteen years, and at their option the right to determine in any year during those periods. The shareholders had therefore fixity of tenure as regards Haimur, in addition to their prospecting rights.

The Chairman continued : — Now with regard to your property at Haimur: during my visit to Egypt last year I visited Haimur in oompany with vour engineer, Mr. Harry Lake, when we made a thorough investigation of the property, and I am leaving England early in January for Egypt and intend to again visit your property with Mr. Lake. A great deal of development work was done at Haimur last season, in the course of wlich a considerable amount of gold was won, the proceeds of which have been placed to your credit, but owing to the fact that under our original holding we were debar- red by the Government from removing any more gold than was necessary to prove the property, practically no sloping was carried out. The bulk of the gold which was removed was that taken from the drives, rises and winzes, which were put in to prove the extent and richness of the mine. All this is now changed. 'ihe rich stone, tho existence of which we had proved but which we were compelled to leave before, we now have tho right under our leasee to win, and this is now beiug done. Tbe pay ground already opened up extends for a considerable distance longi- tudinally, and from tho highest to the lowest points at present opened up is a depth of some 400 to 500 ft. in proving your property, we have used our best endeavours to work on strictly economical linos, and with that end iu view we, have followed the trend of tho veins, putting in adits at different elevations aioug the hili-side and two prospecting shafts in Uie Waili, and where wo have out the formation we have driven on it and followed it down by menus of winzes, connecting up the different drives for purposes of ventila- tion. We still propose to pursue this method of development, and new having obtained our lease we propose to put down our main shaft and develop tbe property at depth. You will see on referring to tho drawing at the end of the report, which shows the trausverso sec- tion of the Haimur workiugs, that at, and uear, the surface on the hill they consist of a series of veins which run parallel, or nearly parallel, to each other. It baa been found, however, as we haye gone down on them that they are converging towards a single point. In fact the formauou suggests a cane which has split into a aeries ol smaller parts at the end although the main body of it remains in one piece. Whilst 1 cannot promise you that these parallel planes make together at one point, there appears from their trend to be a reasonable probability that they do so, and we now propose to put doVru our main shall to open up formation in the neighbourhood where we anticipate this is likely to occur, lu these parallel veins on which wo havo been working the veins have varied in thiokness and in productiveness. Some extraordinarily rich stone has been taken out, and quotiug from the report 1 see that in Adit No. 1. drive N. it is stated “some splendid milling ores have lately oome from tho bottom end of Winze N. giving up to some 50 oz. per ton over 4 to 6 in." On the other hand I see that 5 or. valoes have been obtained over 2 feet of reef, and what is oven more interesting, in the lowest parte of the workings in tho Wadi the formation runs as much as 10 feet wide.

With regard to water, without which, mining in tho desert is an expensive process, I must tell you that water is making its way into the bottom of the shaft in the Wadi, a depth of some 500 ft. from the highest point of tho workings, and approximately 800 ft below W*di level. I do not anticipate that this influx of water is going to create any difficulty, bnc on the contrary is going to be a very valuable asset, and indeed will materially lessen the cost of working there. I hope I have mado it clear to you bom the fore- going remarks that , you have a valuable property in Haimur, in addition to your other interests, that a large amount of pay ground has already been proved and is now being profitably workod, and that your Board propose m the immediate future to farther open up the mine, and generally to develop your pro- perty on energetic lines. I would call your attention to the very moderate capitalisation of your oompany, and in oonoluaion would point oat that a large number of fooee are now being worked and stone is being taken out whichitu estimated will average from £10 to £12 per ton nett profit, and it is anticipated that regular shipments will be made which will enable the Company to develop its property.

div.head: A PAINFUL PORTRAIT.
[Told by a Photographer,]
div.p: “ A photographer is born, not made," said a Camera Artist. He is hewn to endure aa many troubles as the rest of mankind. Mr. Arthur F. Brookes, of 25, Tho Arcade, Wol- verhampton, has travelled through many I countries with his camera, but in London his | professional career was threatened. "1 was ill," j he said, "and none of the doctors knew what was the matter. But Dr. Williams' pink pills i for pale people found my trouble and ourod it 1 was terribly ‘run down.' My nerves seemed to have left me, and at sight of food my stomach would turn. When I forced down a little food to keep up my strength, the pains in my chest were excruciating.

“Two eminent doctors said I was snflering from nervous prostration, and ordered oomplete rest. I was under them six months, but soon after was as ill as ever. 1 had such pain in my bank as to make me cry out and clutch at the first thing I came to.

“I attended a hospital for two months, and my case puzzled evou the clever doctors there. Reduced to a mere skeleton (for eating was impossible) 1 lingered in a dreadful state until four months ago I met an old triend who asked me why 1 didn’t try Dr. Wilburns' pink pills— they always set him up. 1 purchased a box, and it made me a great deaf better. By the time 1 had finished a second box 1 was rapidly putting on flesh. My appetite returned, and 1 enjoy my meals now, without any ill alter-ctlocta. My improved health, after only three boxes, is a revelation. 1 have not toll so well for over ten yean as 1 do at the present I time. There bus never been the least retain of the pain.”

Nerves broken down by irony and work set up the most difficult fora of chronic indi- gestion. Broken uervas are nerves starved for the want of blood. Dr. Williams' pink pills for pale people—genuine only with lull name, seven words—make blood, limy banish aroenua and the pains that afttict the weaker sex. But they are equally valuable for men, having cured indigtnuou, palpitations, bile, nervous depression, sciatica, rheumatism, paralysis, Sl Vitus' dance, and nervous disorders. Two shillings and uwopeuce tor one box, or thirteen and nine tor six sent to Dr. Williams' medians Go., Molboro-viaduot, London, will bring the pills by return poet. But they can be had at medicine shops, it readers insist on the genuine.
It is a Painful Portrait that the Photo- grapher whose case is described above gives of himself. His experience should be a guide to others.
